H0.text: The table is more reactive than the cushion, which explains why a spoon hitting the table makes a loud sound while it does not make a sound when it hits the cushion.

H1.text: The table vibrates more than the cushion, which explains why a spoon striking it makes a loud sound while striking a soft cushion does not.

H2.text: The table is more insulated than the cushion, which accounts for the loud sound a spoon makes when it hits the table compared to the lack of sound when it hits a soft cushion.

H3.text: The table has more potential energy than the cushion, which accounts for the loud sound when a spoon hits it compared to the silence when it hits a soft cushion.

A4.text: dense, hard, impenetrable materials (such as metals) reflect most

A5.text: soft, pliable, or porous materials (like cloths) serve as good acoustic insulators - absorbing most sound
